docs.lead_paragraph: Shuttling from the wedding of the crown prince of Denmark last week to the wedding of the crown prince of Spain this week, the crown prince of Japan, solitary and lonely, was a reminder that royal marriages are not always fairy-tale bliss. Before leaving Japan for a 12-day European tour, Crown Prince Naruhito gave an unprecedented public outburst, telling reporters, essentially, that his Harvard-educated wife was a prisoner of the palace. Princess Masako, a former diplomat, has been reduced to a depressed recluse, he implied, by court bureaucrats obsessed with obtaining a male heir to the Chrysanthemum Throne.

headline.main: Japan Crown Prince Complains Wife Is Stifled by Palace Guard

docs.abstract: Crown Prince Naruhito of Japan, in unprecedented public outburst, tells reporters that his wife, Princess Masako, is prisoner of the palace; implies that court bureaucrats obsessed with obtaining male heir to throne are preventing her from traveling so she might have better chance to conceive; court bureaucrats made little effort to disguise their disappointment when she gave birth to girl in Dec 2001 (M)
docs.snippet: Shuttling from the wedding of the crown prince of Denmark last week to the wedding of the crown prince of Spain this week, the crown prince of Japan, solitary and lonely, was a reminder that royal marriages are not always fairy-tale bliss.    Before...

docs.lead_paragraph: Eating fish regularly late in pregnancy may speed fetal growth, perhaps lowering the risk of having a low-birth-weight baby, according to a new study in The Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. The report is based on a survey of more than 11,500 pregnant women in southwest England. The researchers, from the University of Bristol, said the benefits from eating fish late in pregnancy might have been tied to the omega-3 fatty acids found in fish.
docs.abstract: Dr Imogen Rogers of University of Bristol leads study linking birth weights of newborns and eating fish late in pregnancy; findings, published in Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, shows that women who consumed most fish after 32 weeks of pregnancy had lowest risk of delivering low-weight baby; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'm going to cry.'' Limor Fronimos, 25 weeks pregnant, was taking part in one of the stranger and more controversial outgrowths of the ultrasound industry -- the high-resolution, artistic photography of fetuses -- and was overwhelmed by what she was seeing on the video monitor.

headline.main: Fetal Photos: Keepsake or Health Risk?

docs.abstract: Expectant mothers in Manhattan are having ultrasound procedures recorded at Peek in the Pod, paying up to $295 for packages of photos, CD's, and 20-minute DVD of their fetus that can be sent anywhere to friends and family; bill before state Legislature would ban non-medical use of ultrasound; Food and Drug Administration worries that irressponsible practitioners could subject woman to dangerously long exposure times (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A GOOD marriage is not the first thing that comes to mind when you think of an Edward Albee script, but in the playwright's latest work, called ''Homelife,'' that's what you get, or seem to: a well-off, delicately balanced couple named Ann and Peter. But wait, isn't Peter the name of the buttoned-down Manhattan book editor who has a violent encounter with a hostile loner in Mr. Albee's career-making debut, ''The Zoo Story''?

headline.main: Edward Albee Returns to the Zoo

docs.abstract: Jesse Green interviews Edward Albee, whose first play The Zoo Story will be revived by Hartford Stage Co in Connecticut on same bill with his newest play Homelife; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 59 THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society. 2 4 32 THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife. 3 2 5 *GLORIOUS APPEARING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) In the 12th volume of the ''Left Behind'' series, in which the forces of good battle the forces of evil, the Second Coming occurs. 4 3 4 NIGHTTIME IS MY TIME, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) Determined to avenge himself on the girls who rejected him in high school, a crazed killer targets his 20th class reunion. 5 6 18 ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Atria, $19.95.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society. 6 5 2 THERAPY, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $26.95.) The psychologist-detective Alex Delaware investigates the murder of a couple in a lovers' lane. 7 1 JUST ONE LOOK, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $25.95.) A woman's unearthing of a mysterious photograph leads to the disappearance of her husband and a confrontation with a coldblooded killer. 8 7 2 THE FULL CUPBOARD OF LIFE, by Alexander McCall Smith. (Pantheon, $19.95.) The fifth novel in the No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency series, featuring Mma Ramotswe. 9 11 4 BERGDORF BLONDES, by Plum Sykes. (Miramax/Hyperion, $23.95.) The romantic adventures of an upper-class Manhattan woman and her best friend as they go hunting for ''P.H.'s'' (prospective husbands). 10 1 *A LOVING SCOUNDREL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Atria, $25.) A woman who grew up on the streets of London dreams of becoming a respectable lady. 11 8 3 RECKLESS ABANDON, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) The lawyer and investigator Stone Barrington hunts for a brazen killer in New York City. 12 10 13 THE LAST JUROR, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) In Clanton, Miss., someone is killing off the jurors who sent a man to prison for rape and murder. 13 9 6 CAN YOU KEEP A SECRET? by Sophie Kinsella. (Dial, $21.95.) A woman reveals the most intimate details of her life to a man who turns out to be the C.E.O. of the company for which she works. 14 12 3 GOOD GRIEF, by Lolly Winston. (Warner, $18.) A young woman whose husband died gives up her dream of being ''a good widow'' and seeks a brand-new life. 15 9 15*THE BIRTH OF VENUS, by Sarah Dunant. (Random House, $21.95.) In Renaissance Florence, a young wife struggles with her attraction to a painter. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 2 PLAN OF ATTACK, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A behind-the-scenes account of the Bush administration's decision making as it drew up plans to invade Iraq and overthrow Saddam Hussein. 2 2 4 EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks. 3 4 3 THREE WEEKS WITH MY BROTHER, by Nicholas Sparks and Micah Sparks. (Warner, $22.) The novelist and his sibling describe their trip around the world. 4 3 6 AGAINST ALL ENEMIES, by Richard A. Clarke. (Free Press, $27.) President Bush's former counterterrorism coordinator criticizes the administration's handling of events before and after the 9/11 attacks. 5 1 ALEXANDER HAMILTON, by Ron Chernow. (Penguin Press, $35.) A biography of the first Treasury secretary and chief author of The Federalist Papers. 6 5 5 WORSE THAN WATERGATE, by John W. Dean. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The man who served as counsel to President Richard Nixon offers an indictment of the Bush administration. 7 6 3 FOUNDING MOTHERS, by Cokie Roberts. (Morrow, $24.95.) The ABC News commentator details the lives of the many women (Abigail Adams and Martha Washington among them) who ''raised our nation.'' 8 11 2 ON THE DOWN LOW, by J. L. King with Karen Hunter. (Broadway, $21.95.) Exploring the lives of ostensibly straight black men who have sex with men, and the health consequences for the black community. 9 1 BELLY LAUGHS, by Jenny McCarthy. (Da Capo/Lifelong, $18.) The former MTV host discusses ''the naked truth about pregnancy and childbirth.'' 10 12 4 CADDY FOR LIFE, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The story of Bruce Edwards, Tom Watson's longtime caddie, who died last month after struggling for more than a year with A.L.S. 11 1 SECRETS OF THE CODE, edited by Dan Burstein. (CDS Books/Squibnocket, $21.95.) Essays by a variety of experts -- theologians, art historians, scientists -- on themes relating to ''The Da Vinci Code.'' 12 8 5 *TEN MINUTES FROM NORMAL, by Karen Hughes. (Viking, $25.95.) The autobiography of a close adviser to President Bush. 13 7 11 DELIVER US FROM EVIL, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $26.95.) The radio and television personality argues that the war on terror must involve the defeat of liberalism as well as despotism. 14 1 BREAKING THE DA VINCI CODE, by Darrell L. Bock. (Nelson Books, $19.99.) A critique of ''The Da Vinci Code'' by a professor of New Testament studies. 15 14 3 FAREWELL, JACKIE, by Edward Klein. (Viking, $23.95.) An account of the final months in the life of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Children's Picture Books 1 5 IF ROAST BEEF COULD FLY, by Jay Leno. Illustrated by S. B. Whitehead. (Byron Preiss/Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The television host and comic recounts an anecdote from his childhood. (Ages 5 to 8) 2 2 267 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) The problems of finding your way through life. (Ages 8 and up) 3 1 3 I ALREADY KNOW I LOVE YOU, by Billy Crystal. Illustrated by Elizabeth Sayles. (HarperCollins, $16.99.) Awaiting the birth of a grandchild. (Ages 4 to 8) 4 3 62 WALTER THE FARTING DOG, by William Kotzwinkle and Glenn Murray. Illustrated by Audrey Colman. (Frog Ltd./North Atlantic, $15.95.) The trials and triumphs of a flatulent mutt. (Ages 4 to 8) 5 10 2 MISTER SEAHORSe, written and illustrated by Eric Carle. (Philomel, $16.99.) The ways in which certain fish fathers care for their young. (Ages 4 to 8) 6 4 6 WALTER THE FARTING DOG: Trouble at the Yard Sale, by William Kotzwinkle and Glenn Murray. Illustrated by Audrey Colman. (Dutton, $15.99.) A flatulent mutt wreaks further havoc. (Ages 4 to 8) 7 7 15 THE MAN WHO WALKED BETWEEN THE TOWERS, written and illustrated by Mordicai Gerstein. (Roaring Brook, $17.95.) The story of Philippe Petit's high-wire feat at the World Trade Center. (Ages 5 to 8) 8 9 15 DR. ERNEST DRAKE'S DRAGONOLOGY, edited by Dugald A. Steer. (Candlewick, $18.99.) The complete book of dragons. (Ages 8 and up) 9 8 9 DUCK FOR PRESIDENT, by Doreen Cronin. Illustrated by Betsy Lewin. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) A duck decides to hit the campaign trail. (Ages 4 to 8) 10 25 TAILS, written and illustrated by Matthew Van Fleet. Edited by Skip Skwarek. (Red Wagon/Harcourt, $12.95.) All about them, the furry and the rough. (Ages 2 to 5) Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 1, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no surprise to Jerrold M. Post, the founder of the Center for the Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior at the C.I.A., that Saddam Hussein grew up to be one of the world's most dangerous dictators and a member of President Bush's axis of evil. ''Of all of the leaders I've profiled, his background is assuredly the most traumatic,'' Dr. Post said in an interview this week in his wood-paneled, African-artifact-filled office in Bethesda, Md., where he is a psychiatrist for patients whose personal struggles have typically not led to two American wars in the Middle East. ''His troubles can really be traced back to the womb.''

headline.main: Was a Tyrant Prefigured by Baby Saddam?

docs.abstract: Jerrold Post, founder of CIA's Center for Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior, says, in interview, that he is not surprised that Saddam Hussein grew up to be one of world's most dangerous dictators; Post, author of new book Leaders and Their Followers in a Dangerous World, says Hussein is 'judicious political calculator' not madman; says understanding minds of rogue leaders is essential to developing policies to counteract them; photos (M)
